description: From Middle English averten, adverten, from Old French avertir (“turn, direct, avert; turn the attention, make aware”), from Latin āvertere, present active infinitive of āvertō, from ab + vertō (“to turn”).

verbs.description: avert (third-person singular simple present averts, present participle averting, simple past and past participle averted)

examples: I averted my eyes while my friend typed in her password.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To ward off, or prevent, the occurrence or effects of.
examples: How can the danger be averted?
Cold and averting from our neighbour's good.
